title: The Novel Cure by Ella Berthoud
description:
The Novel Cure: From Abandonment to Zestlessness: 751 Books to Cure What Ails You by Ella Berthoud, Susan Elderkin

A novel is a story transmitted from the novelist to the reader. It offers distraction, entertainment, and an opportunity to unwind or focus. But it can also be something more powerfulÃ¢â‚¬â€a way to learn about how to live. Read at the right moment in your life, a novel canÃ¢â‚¬â€quite literallyÃ¢â‚¬â€change it.

The Novel Cure is a reminder of that power. To create this apothecary, the authors have trawled two thousand years of literature for novels that effectively promote happiness, health, and sanity, written by brilliant minds who knew what it meant to be human and wrote their life lessons into their fiction. Structured like a reference book, readers simply look up their ailment, be it agoraphobia, boredom, or a midlife crisis, and are given a novel to read as the antidote. 

Bibliotherapy does not discriminate between pains of the body and pains of the head (or heart). Aware that youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve been cowardly? Pick up To Kill a Mockingbird for an injection of courage. Experiencing a sudden, acute fear of death? Read One Hundred Years of Solitude for some perspective on the larger cycle of life. Nervous about throwing a dinner party? Ali SmithÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s There but for The will convince you that yours could never go that wrong. 

Whatever your condition, the prescription is simple: a novel (or two), to be read at regular intervals and in nice long chunks until you finish. Some treatments will lead to a complete cure. Others will offer solace, showing that youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re not the first to experience these emotions. The Novel Cure is also peppered with useful lists and sidebars recommending the best novels to read when youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re stuck in traffic or canÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t fall asleep, the most important novels to read during every decade of life, and many more.

Brilliant in concept and deeply satisfying in execution, The Novel Cure belongs on everyoneÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s bookshelf and in every medicine cabinet. It will make even the most well-read fiction aficionado pick up a novel heÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s never heard of, and see familiar ones with new eyes. Mostly, it will reaffirm literatureÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s ability to distract and transport, to resonate and reassure, to change the way we see the world and our place in it.
